parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This certificate policy (CP) includes many distinct certificate policies: a policy for users with software cryptographic modules, a policy for users with hardware cryptographic modules, a policy for devices with software cryptographic modules, a policy for devices with hardware cryptographic modules, a policy for devices that sign PIV data objects, a high assurance user policy, three user authentication policies, and a card authentication policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In this document, the term “device” means a non-person entity, i.e., a hardware device or software application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a specific policy is not stated, the policies and procedures in this specification apply equally to all policies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of SHA-1 to create digital signatures is not allowed under Common Policy after 12/31/2013.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The user policies apply to certificates issued to Federal employees, contractors, and other affiliated personnel for the purposes of authentication, signature, and confidentiality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP was explicitly designed to support access to Federal systems that have not been designated national security systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A PKI that uses this CP will provide the following security management services:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Key generation/storage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate generation, modification, re-key, and distribution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate revocation list (CRL) generation and distribution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Directory management of certificate related items

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate token initialization/programming/management

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - System management functions (e.g., security audit, configuration management, archive.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The user policies require Federal employees, contractors, and other affiliated personnel to use FIPS 140 validated cryptographic modules for cryptographic operations and the protection of trusted public keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The device policy also requires use of FIPS 140 validated cryptographic modules for cryptographic operations and the protection of trusted public keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy does not presume any particular PKI architecture.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The policy may be implemented through a hierarchical PKI, mesh PKI, or a single certification authority (CA).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any CA that asserts this policy in certificates must obtain prior approval from the Federal PKI Policy Authority.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that issue certificates under this policy may operate simultaneously under other policies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such CAs must not assert the OIDs in this policy in certificates unless they are issued in accordance with all the requirements of this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy establishes requirements for the secure distribution of self-signed certificates for use as trust anchors.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These constraints apply only to CAs that chose to distribute self-signed certificates, such as a hierarchical PKI’s root CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP is consistent with request for comments (RFC) 3647, the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) Public Key Infrastructure X.509 (IETF PKIX) Certificate Policy and Certification Practices Framework.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this policy contain a registered certificate policy object identifier (OID), which may be used by a relying party to decide whether a certificate is trusted for a particular purpose.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP applies only to CAs owned by or operated on behalf of the Federal government that issue certificates according to this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP states what assurance can be placed in a certificate issued by the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The certification practice statement (CPS) states how the CA establishes that assurance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CA that issues certificates under this CP shall have a corresponding CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP applies to certificates issued to CAs, devices, and Federal employees, contractors and other affiliated personnel.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP does not apply to certificates issued to groups of people.

controls.title: Interoperation with CAs Issuing under Different Policies

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Except for legacy Federal PKIs, interoperation with CAs that issue under different policies will be achieved through policy mapping and cross-certification through the Federal Bridge Certification Authority.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legacy Federal PKIs may perform policy mapping and cross-certification with either the Common Policy Root CA or Federal Bridge Certification Authority at their discretion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Note that interoperability may also be achieved through other means, such as trust lists, to meet local requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP provides substantial assurance concerning identity of certificate subjects.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued in accordance with this CP and associated with the Federal Common Policy Root CA shall assert at least one of the following OIDs in the certificate policy extension:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to CAs may contain a subset of these OIDs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to users, other than devices, to support digitally signed documents or key management may contain either id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, or id-fpki-common-High.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates issued to devices under this policy that use FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher cryptographic modules shall include one or more of id-fpki-common-deviceHardware, or id-fpki-common-devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates issued to devices under this policy using software cryptographic modules shall include id-fpki-common-devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This document includes five policies specific to FIPS 201 Personal Identity Verification (PIV) of Federal Employees and Contractors.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to users supporting authentication but not digital signature, where the corresponding private key is stored on a PIV Card, may contain id-fpki-common-authentication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to users supporting authentication where the private key is stored on a PIV Card and can be used without user authentication may contain id-fpki-common-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to users, in accordance with NIST SP 800-157, supporting authentication, but not digital signature, where the corresponding private key is not stored on a PIV Card, may contain either id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware or id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth as appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning policy shall only be asserted in certificates issued to devices that sign PIV data objects in accordance with \[FIPS 201\] or \[SP 800-157\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to users supporting authentication where the private key is stored on a Common PIV-I credential and requires user authentication shall contain id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued to users supporting authentication where the private key is stored on a Common PIV-I credential and can be used without user authentication shall contain id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning policy shall only be asserted in certificates issued to devices that sign Common PIV-I credential data objects.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements associated with id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication and id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth are identical to id-fpki-common-authentication and id-fpki-common-cardAuth, respectively, with the exception of the need for a NACI and associated favorable adjudication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For additional comparisons, see Appendix A.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements associated with id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning and id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning are identical to id-fpki-common-devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hardware, except where specifically noted in the text.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The following are roles relevant to the administration and operation of CAs under this policy:

groups.title: Federal Chief Information Officers Council Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Federal CIO Council comprises the Chief Information Officers of all cabinet level departments and other independent agencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Federal CIO Council has established the framework for the interoperable Federal PKI (FPKI) and oversees the operation of the organizations responsible for governing and promoting its use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In particular, this CP was established under the authority of and with the approval of the Federal CIO Council.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA is a group of U.S. Federal Government Agencies (including cabinet-level Departments) chartered by the Federal CIO Council.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA owns this policy and represents the interest of the Federal CIOs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA is responsible for:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Maintaining this CP,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Approving the CPS for each CA that issues certificates under this policy,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Approving the compliance audit report for each CA issuing certificates under this policy, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring continued conformance of each CA that issues certificates under this policy with applicable requirements as a condition for allowing continued participation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIMA is the organization that operates and maintains the Common Policy Root CAs on behalf of the U.S. Government, subject to the direction of the FPKIPA.

groups.title: FPKI Management Authority Program Manager Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Program Manager is the individual within the FPKIMA who has principal responsibility for overseeing the proper operation of the Common Policy Root CAs including the required repository, and selecting the FPKIMA staff.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Program Manager is selected by the FPKIMA and reports to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIMA Program Manager must hold a Top Secret security clearance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each organization that provides PKI services under this policy shall identify an individual or group that is responsible for maintaining the Shared Service Provider’s (SSP) CPS and for ensuring that all SSP PKI components (e.g., CAs, CSSs, CMSs, RAs) are operated in compliance with the SSP CPS and this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This body is referred to as the SSP PMA within this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Agencies that contract for the services of a CA under this policy, shall establish a management body to manage any agency-operated components (e.g., RAs or repositories) and resolve name space collisions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This body shall be referred to as an Agency Policy Management Authority, or Agency PMA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An SSP PMA shall be responsible for notifying its customer Agency PMAs and the FPKIPA of any change to the infrastructure that has the potential to affect the FPKI operational environment at least two weeks prior to implementation; all new artifacts (CA certificates, CRL DP, AIA and/or SIA URLs, etc.) produced as a result of the change shall be provided to the FPKIPA within 24 hours following implementation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An Agency PMA is responsible for ensuring that all Agency operated PKI components (e.g., CAs, CSSs, CMSs, RAs) are operated in compliance with this CP and the applicable CPS and shall serve as the liaison for that agency to the FPKIPA and the SSP PMA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA is the collection of hardware, software and operating personnel that create, sign, and issue public key certificates to subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA is responsible for the issuing and managing certificates including:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The certificate manufacturing process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Publication of certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Revocation of certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Generation and destruction of CA signing keys

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring that all aspects of the CA services, operations, and infrastructure related to certificates issued under this CP are performed in accordance with the requirements, representations, and warranties of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PKIs may optionally include an authority that provides status information about certificates on behalf of a CA through on-line transactions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In particular, PKIs may include OCSP responders to provide on-line status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such an authority is termed a certificate status server (CSS).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the CSS is identified in certificates as an authoritative source for revocation information, the operations of that authority are considered within the scope of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Certificate Status Server (CSS) shall assert all the policy OIDs for which it is authoritative.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples include OCSP servers that are identified in the authority information access (AIA) extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: OCSP servers that are locally trusted, as described in \[RFC 6960\], are not covered by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The registration authorities (RAs) collect and verify each subscriber’s identity and information that is to be entered into the subscriber’s public key certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA performs its function in accordance with a CPS approved by the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA is responsible for:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Control over the registration process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The identification and authentication process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The trusted agent is a person who satisfies all the trustworthiness requirements for an RA and who performs identity proofing as a proxy for the RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The trusted agent records information from and verifies biometrics (e.g., photographs) on presented credentials for applicants who cannot appear in person at an RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS will identify the parties responsible for providing such services, and the mechanisms for determining their trustworthiness.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A subscriber is the entity whose name appears as the subject in a certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The subscriber asserts that he or she uses the key and certificate in accordance with the certificate policy asserted in the certificate, and does not issue certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For this policy, subscribers are limited to Federal employees, contractors, affiliated personnel, and devices operated by or on behalf of Federal agencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs are sometimes technically considered “subscribers” in a PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: However, the term “subscriber” as used in this document refers only to those who request certificates for uses other than signing and issuing certificates or certificate status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is a subset of human subscribers who will be issued role-based certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These certificates will identify a specific role on behalf of which the subscriber is authorized to act rather than the subscriber’s name and are issued in the interest of supporting accepted business practices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The role-based certificate can be used in situations where non-repudiation is desired.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Normally, it will be issued in addition to an individual subscriber certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A specific role may be identified in certificates issued to multiple subscribers, however, the key pair will be unique to each individual role-based certificate (i.e. there may be four individuals carrying a certificate issued in the role of “Secretary of Commerce” however, each of the four individual certificates will carry unique keys and certificate identifiers).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles for which role-based certificates may be issued are limited to those that are held by a unique individual within an organization (e.g.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: *Chief Information Officer, GSA* is a unique individual whereas *Program Analyst, GSA* is not).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When determining whether a role-based certificate is authorized, consider whether the role carries inherent authority beyond the job title.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Role-based certificates may also be used for individuals on temporary assignment, where the temporary assignment carries an authority not shared by the individuals in their usual occupation, for example: “*Watch Commander, Task Force 1*”.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A relying party is the entity that relies on the validity of the binding of the subscriber’s name to a public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The relying party is responsible for deciding whether or how to check the validity of the certificate by checking the appropriate certificate status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The relying party can use the certificate to verify the integrity of a digitally signed message, to identify the creator of a message, or to establish confidential communications with the holder of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A relying party may use information in the certificate (such as CP identifiers) to determine the suitability of the certificate for a particular use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For this certificate policy, the relying party may be any entity that wishes to validate the binding of a public key to the name (or role) of a federal employee, contractor, or other affiliated personnel.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CAs and RAs operating under this CP may require the services of other security, community, and application authorities, such as compliance auditors and attribute authorities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS will identify the parties responsible for providing such services, and the mechanisms used to support these services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The sensitivity of the information processed or protected using certificates issued by the CA will vary significantly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organizations must evaluate the environment and the associated threats and vulnerabilities and determine the level of risk they are willing to accept based on the sensitivity or significance of the information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This evaluation is done by each organization for each application and is not controlled by this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP is intended to support the use of validated public keys to access Federal systems that have not been designated national security systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: While a validated public key is not generally sufficient to grant access the key may be sufficient when supplemented by appropriate authorization mechanisms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Credentials issued under this CP may also be used for key establishment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy is intended to support applications involving unclassified information, which can include sensitive unclassified data protected pursuant to federal statutes and regulations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Credentials issued under the id-fpki-common-policy and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth policies are intended to meet the requirements for Level 3 authentication, as defined by the OMB E‑Authentication Guidance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: \[E-Auth\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Credentials issued under the id-fpki-common-hardware, id-fpki-common-authentication id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, and id-fpki-common-High policies meet the requirements for Level 4 authentication, as defined by the OMB E-Authentication Guidance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: \[E-Auth\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Credentials issued under the id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning policy are intended to meet the requirements in FIPS 201 and SP 800-157 as the digital signatory of the PIV Card Holder Unique IDentifier (CHUID) and associated PIV data objects.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, this policy may support signature and confidentiality requirements for Federal government processes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that assert id-fpki-common-cardAuth or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth shall only be used to authenticate the hardware token containing the associated private key and shall not be interpreted as authenticating the presenter or holder of the token.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA is responsible for all aspects of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Questions regarding this CP shall be directed to the Chair of the Federal PKI Policy

Person Determining CPS Suitability for the Policy Controls

controls.title: Person Determining CPS Suitability for the Policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall approve the CPS for each CA that issues certificates under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs issuing under this policy are required to meet all facets of the policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will not issue waivers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall make the determination that a CPS complies with this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA and RA must meet all requirements of an approved CPS before commencing operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In some cases, the FPKIPA may require the additional approval of an authorized agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will make this determination based on the nature of the system function, the type of communications, or the operating environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In each case, the determination of suitability shall be based on an independent compliance auditor’s results and recommendations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See section 8 for further details.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See sections 11 and 12.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CAs that issue certificates under this policy are obligated to post all CA certificates issued by or to the CA and CRLs issued by the CA in a repository that is publicly accessible through all Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) references asserted in valid certificates issued by that CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Specific requirements are found in *Shared Service Provider Repository Service Requirements* \[SSP REP\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs may optionally post subscriber certificates in this repository in accordance with agency policy, except as noted in section 9.4.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To promote consistent access to certificates and CRLs, the repository shall implement access controls and communication mechanisms to prevent unauthorized modification or deletion of information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Posted certificates and CRLs may be replicated in additional repositories for performance enhancement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such repositories may be operated by the CA or other parties (e.g., Federal agencies).

groups.title: 3.2.0 Publication of Certificates and Certificate Status
Publication of Certificates and Certificate Status Controls

controls.title: Publication of Certificates and Certificate Status

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The publicly accessible repository system shall be designed and implemented so as to provide 99% availability overall and limit scheduled down-time to 0.5% annually.

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, id-fpki-common-High, id-fpki-common-devices and id-fpki-common-devicesHardware the CA shall assign X.501 distinguished names to all subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These distinguished names may be in either of two forms: a geo-political name or an Internet domain component name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All geo-political distinguished names assigned to federal employees shall be in the following directory information tree:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organizational units *department* and *agency* appear when applicable and are used to specify the federal entity that employs the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one of these organizational units must appear in the DN.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The additional organizational unit *structural_container* is permitted to support local directory requirements, such as differentiation between human subscribers and devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This organizational unit may not be employed to further differentiate between subcomponents within an agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The distinguished name of the federal employee subscriber shall take one of the three following forms:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*nickname lastname*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*firstname initial.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: lastname*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*firstname middlename lastname*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the first name form, *nickname* may be the subscriber’s first name, a form of the first name, middle name, or pseudonym (e.g., Buck) by which the subscriber is generally known.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A generational qualifier, such as “Sr.” or “III”, may be appended to any of the common name forms specified above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Distinguished names assigned to federal contractors and other affiliated persons shall be within the same directory information tree.

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*firstname initial.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: lastname* (affiliate)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*firstname middlename lastname* (affiliate)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For names assigned to federal contractors and other affiliated persons, generational qualifiers may be inserted between *lastname* and “(affiliate)”.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Common name fields shall be populated as specified above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Distinguished names based on Internet domain component names shall be in the following directory information trees:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=mil, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[ dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The default Internet domain name for the agency, \[*orgN*.\]…\[*org0*\].gov or \[*orgN*.\]…\[*org0*\].mil, will be used to determine DNs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The first domain component of the DN will either be dc=gov or dc=mil.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the *org0* domain component must appear in the DN.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The *org1* to *orgN* domain components appear, in order, when applicable and are used to specify the federal entity that employs the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The distinguished name of the federal employee subscriber shall take one of the three following forms when their agency’s Internet domain name ends in .gov:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*nickname lastname*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*firstname initial.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*firstname middlename lastname*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The distinguished name of the federal contractors and affiliated subscribers shall take one of the three following forms when the agency’s Internet domain name ends in .gov:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*nickname lastname* (affiliate)
