parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA may supplement any of the name forms for users specified in this section by including a dnQualifier, serial number, or user id attribute.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When any of these attributes are included, they may appear as part of a multi-valued relative distinguished name (RDN) with the common name or as a distinct RDN that follows the RDN containing the common name attribute.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Generational qualifiers may optionally be included in common name attributes in distinguished names based on Internet domain names.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For names assigned to employees, generational qualifiers may be appended to the common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For names assigned to federal contractors and other affiliated persons, generational qualifiers may be inserted between *lastname* and “(affiliate)”.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Signature certificates issued under id-fpki-common-hardware or id-fpki-common-High may be issued with a common name that specifies an organizational role, such as the head of an agency, as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*role* \[*, department/agency*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=…, \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*role* \[, *department/agency*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The combination of organizational role and agency must unambiguously identify a single person.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (That is, widely held roles such as *Computer Scientist* or *Procurement Specialist* cannot be included since they do not identify a particular person.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: *Chief Information Officer*, *AgencyX* could be included as it specifies a role held by a single person.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the \[department/agency\] is implicit in the role (e.g., Secretary of Commerce), it should be omitted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the role alone is ambiguous (e.g., Chief Information Officer) the department/agency must be present in the common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organizational information in the common name must match that in the organizational unit attributes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case of “Chief Information Officer”, use of department/agency in the common name is redundant but is included for usability purposes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Display of the common name is widely supported in applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Other attributes may or may not be presented to users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Devices that are the subject of certificates issued under this policy shall be assigned either a geo‑political name or an Internet domain component name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device names shall take one of the following forms:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=department\], \[ou=agency\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], cn=*device name*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[*dc=org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], \[cn=*device name*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=mil, dc=*org0*, \[*dc=org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], \[cn=*device name*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: where *device name* is a descriptive name for the device.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a device is fully described by the Internet domain name, the common name attribute is optional.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates that assert serverAuth in the EKU:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Wildcard Domain Names are permitted if all sub-domains covered by the wildcard fall within the same application, cloud service, or system accreditation boundary within the scope of the sponsoring Agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Wildcards shall not be used in subdomains that host more than one distinct application platform.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of third-level Agency wildcards, (e.g., \*.\[agency\].gov), shall be prohibited to reduce the likelihood that a certificate will overlap multiple systems or services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Third level wildcards are permitted for DNS names dedicated to a specific application (e.g., \*.\[application_name\].gov).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Before issuing a serverAuth certificate containing a wildcard, the CA shall ensure the sponsoring agency has a documented procedure for determining that the scope of the certificate does not now and will not infringe on other agency applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy does not restrict the directory information tree for names of CAs and CSSs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: However, CAs that issue certificates under this policy must have distinguished names.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA and CSS distinguished names may be either a geo-political name or an Internet domain component name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA and CSS geo-political distinguished names shall be composed of any combination of the following attributes: country; organization; organizational unit; and common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Internet domain component names are composed of the following attributes: domain component; organizational unit; and common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Common PIV Content Signing certificate’s subject DN shall indicate the organization administering the PIV card issuance system or device according to types of names for devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth shall include a non-empty subject DN and shall also include a subject alternative name extension that includes a UUID, which shall be encoded as a URI as specified in Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A unique UUID shall be created for each certificate issued under one of these policies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under this policy by a CA operating as part of the Shared Service Providers program, subject distinguished names shall follow either the rules specified above for id‑fpki-common-hardware or the rules specified below for including a non-NULL subject DN with a UUID in id-fpki-common-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For legacy Federal PKIs only, distinguished names may follow established agency naming conventions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication or id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, assignment of X.500 distinguished names is mandatory.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under this policy by a CA operating as part of the Shared Service Providers program, distinguished names shall follow either the rules specified above for id‑fpki-common-hardware or the rules specified below for including a non-NULL subject DN in id-fpki-common-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For legacy Federal PKIs only, distinguished names may follow established agency naming conventions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication or id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication shall include a subject alternative name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates asserting id-fpki-common-authentication, at a minimum, the subject alternative name extension shall include:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  the pivFASC-N name type \[FIPS 201\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The value for this name shall be the FASC-N \[PACS\] of the subject’s PIV card

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  The UUID \[RFC 4122\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates asserting id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, at a minimum, the subject alternative name extension shall include:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  The UUID \[RFC 4122\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-cardAuth shall include a subject alternative name extension that includes the pivFASC-N name type.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The value for this name shall be the FASC-N of the subject’s PIV card.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-cardAuth shall also include a UUID \[RFC 4122\] in the subject alternative name extension, as specified in Section 3.3 of \[SP 800-73-3(1)\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth shall only include a UUID \[RFC 4122\] in the subject alternative name extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-cardAuth or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth shall not include any other name in the subject alternative name extension but may include a non-NULL name in the subject field.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If included, the subject distinguished name shall take one of the following forms:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV Examples:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], serialNumber=*FASC-N*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[*dc=org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], serialNumber=*FASC-N*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=mil, dc=*org0*, \[*dc=org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], serialNumber=*FASC-N*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV or PIV-I Examples:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, \[ou=*department*\], \[ou=*agency*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], serialNumber=*UUID*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], serialNumber=*UUID*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=mil, dc=*org0*, \[dc=*org1*\], …, \[dc=*orgN*\], \[ou=*structural_container*\], serialNumber=*UUID*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note: The FASC-N \[PACS\] consists of 40 decimal digits that are encoded as a 25-byte binary value.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This 25-byte binary value may be encoded directly into the pivFASC-N name type in the subject alternative name extension, but when included in the subject field the FASC-N must be encoded as a PrintableString that is at most 64 characters long.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy does not mandate any particular method for encoding the FASC-N within the serial number attribute as long as the same encoding method is used for all certificates issued by a CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Acceptable methods for encoding the FASC-N within the serial number attribute include encoding the 25-byte binary value as 50 bytes of ASCII HEX or encoding the 40 decimal digits as 40 bytes of ASCII decimal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When the UUID appears in the subjectAltName extension of a certificate, it must be encoded as a uniformResourceIdentifier as specified in Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An example of a UUID encoded as a URI, from RFC 4122, is “urn:uuid:f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6”.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy does not mandate any particular method for encoding the UUID within the serial number attribute as long as the same encoding method is used for all certificates issued by the CA and it is encoded as a PrintableString that is at most 64 characters long, however, it is recommended that the string representation from Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\] be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An example would be “f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6”.

groups.title: 4.1.1 Need for Names to Be Meaningful
Need for Names to Be Meaningful Controls

controls.title: Need for Names to Be Meaningful

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The subscriber certificates issued pursuant to this CP are meaningful only if the names that appear in the certificates can be understood and used by relying parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Names used in the certificates must identify in a meaningful way the subscriber to which they are assigned.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The common name in the DN must represent the subscriber in a way that is easily understandable for humans.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For people, this will typically be a legal name, so the preferred common name form is

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: > cn=*firstname initial.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: lastname*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: While the issuer name in CA certificates is not generally interpreted by relying parties, this CP still requires use of meaningful names by CAs issuing under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If included, the common name should describe the issuer, such as:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: > cn=*AgencyX CA-3*

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The subject name in CA certificates must match the issuer name in certificates issued by the subject, as required by RFC 5280.

groups.title: Anonymity or Pseudonymity of Subscribers Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall not issue anonymous certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Pseudonymous certificates may be issued by the CA to support internal operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs may also issue pseudonymous certificates that identify subjects by their organizational roles, as described in section 3.1.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates issued by the CA shall not contain anonymous or pseudonymous identities.

groups.title: 4.1.3 Rules for Interpreting Various Name Forms
Rules for Interpreting Various Name Forms Controls

controls.title: Rules for Interpreting Various Name Forms

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for interpreting distinguished name forms are specified in X.501.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for interpreting e‑mail addresses are specified in \[RFC 5322\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for interpreting the pivFASC-N name type are specified in \[PACS\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Name uniqueness for certificates issued by each CA must be enforced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CA and its associated RAs shall enforce name uniqueness within the X.500 name space.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When other name forms are used, they too must be allocated such that name uniqueness is ensured for certificates issued by that CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Name uniqueness is not violated when multiple certificates are issued to the same entity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS shall identify the method for the assignment of subject names.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Directory information trees may be assigned to a single CA, or shared between CAs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where multiple CAs share a single directory information tree, the FPKIPA shall review and approve the method for assignment of subject names.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For distinguished names, name uniqueness is enforced for the entire name rather than a particular attribute (e.g., the common name).

groups.title: 4.1.5 Recognition, Authentication, and Role of Trademarks
Recognition, Authentication, and Role of Trademarks Controls

controls.title: Recognition, Authentication, and Role of Trademarks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy shall not issue a certificate knowing that it infringes the trademark of another.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall resolve disputes involving names and trademarks.

groups.title: 4.2.0 Method to Prove Possession of Private Key
Method to Prove Possession of Private Key Controls

controls.title: Method to Prove Possession of Private Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In all cases where the party named in a certificate generates its own keys, that party shall be required to prove possession of the private key, which corresponds to the public key in the certificate request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For signature keys, this may be done by the entity using its private key to sign a value supplied by the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall then validate the signature using the party’s public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA may allow other mechanisms that are at least as secure as those cited here.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case where key generation is performed under the CA or RA’s direct control, proof of possession is not required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests for CA certificates shall include the CA name, address, and documentation of the existence of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before issuing CA certificates, an authority for the issuing CA shall verify the information, in addition to the authenticity of the requesting representative and the representative’s authorization to act in the name of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy allows a certificate to be issued only to a single entity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates shall not be issued that contain a public key whose associated private key is shared.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures used by agencies to issue identification to their own personnel and affiliates may be more stringent than that set forth below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When this is the case, the agency procedures for authentication of personnel shall apply in addition to the guidance in this section.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA shall ensure that the applicant’s identity information is verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identity shall be verified no more than 30 days before initial certificate issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At id-fpki-common-High, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-authentication, and id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, the applicant shall appear at the RA in person or via supervised remote[^1].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other policies, RAs may accept authentication of an applicant’s identity attested to and documented by a trusted agent, assuming agency identity badging requirements are otherwise satisfied.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication by a trusted agent does not relieve the RA of its responsibility to verify required procedures were followed as described below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, authentication procedures for employees must include the following steps:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  Verify that a request for certificate issuance to the applicant was submitted by agency management.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  Verify Applicant’s employment through use of official agency records.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3)  Establish applicant’s identity by in-person or supervised remote proofing before the registration authority or trusted agent, as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  The applicant presents a government-issued form of identification (e.g., an Agency ID badge, a passport, or driver’s license) as proof of identity, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  The RA examines the presented credential for biometric data that can be linked to the applicant (e.g., a photograph on the credential itself or a securely linked photograph of applicant), and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  The credential presented in step 3) a) above shall be verified by the RA for currency and legitimacy (e.g., the agency ID is verified as valid).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Typically, this is accomplished by querying a database maintained by the organization that issued the credential, but other equivalent methods may be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4)  Record and maintain a biometric of the applicant (e.g., a photograph or fingerprint) by the RA or CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Handwritten signatures and other behavioral characteristics are not accepted as biometrics for the purposes of this policy.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This establishes an audit trail for dispute resolution.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For contractors and other affiliated personnel, the authentication procedures must include the following steps:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  Verify that a request for certificate issuance to the applicant was submitted by an authorized sponsoring agency employee (e.g., contracting officer or contracting officer’s technical representative).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  Verify sponsoring agency employee’s identity and employment as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  A digitally signed request from the sponsoring agency employee, verified by a currently valid employee signature certificate issued by an agency CA, may be accepted as proof of both employment and identity,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  Authentication of the sponsoring agency employee with a valid employee PIV-authentication certificate issued by the agency may be accepted as proof of both employment and identity, or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  In-person or supervised remote identity proofing of the sponsoring agency employee may be established before the registration authority as specified in employee authentication above and employment validated through use of the official agency records.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3)  Establish applicant’s identity by in-person or supervised remote proofing before the registration authority or trusted agent, as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  The applicant presents a government-issued form of identification (e.g., an Agency ID badge, a passport, or driver’s license) as proof of identity, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  The RA examines the presented credential for biometric data that can be linked to the applicant (e.g., a photograph on the credential itself or a securely linked photograph of applicant), and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  The credential presented in step 3) a) above shall be verified by the RA for currency and legitimacy (e.g., the agency ID is verified as valid).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Typically, this is accomplished by querying official records maintained by the organization that issued the credential.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4)  Record and maintain a biometric of the applicant (e.g., a photograph or fingerprint) by the RA or CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Handwritten signatures and other behavioral characteristics are not accepted as biometrics for the purposes of this policy.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This establishes an audit trail for dispute resolution.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event an applicant is denied a credential based on the results of the identity proofing process, the Entity shall provide a mechanism for appeal or redress of the decision.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additionally, the RA shall record the process that was followed for issuance of each certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The process documentation and authentication requirements shall include the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The identity of the person performing the identification;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A signed declaration by that person that he or she verified the identity of the Applicant as required by the CPS using the format set forth at 28 U.S.C. 1746 (declaration under penalty of perjury);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Unique identifying number(s) from the ID(s) of the applicant, or a facsimile of the ID(s);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The biometric of the applicant;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The date and time of the verification; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A declaration of identity signed by the applicant using a handwritten signature or appropriate digital signature and performed in the presence of the person performing the identity authentication, using the format set forth at 28 U.S.C. 1746 (declaration under penalty of perjury).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Some computing and communications devices (routers, firewalls, servers, etc.) and software applications will be named as certificate subjects.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In such cases, the device must have a human sponsor who is affiliated with the agency under which the certificate is being issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The sponsor is responsible for providing the following registration information:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment identification (e.g., serial number) or service name (e.g., DNS name) or unique software application name

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment or software application public keys

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment or software application authorizations and attributes (if any are to be included in the certificate)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Contact information to enable the CA or RA to communicate with the sponsor when required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These certificates shall be issued only to authorized devices under the subscribing organization’s control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case a human sponsor is changed, the new sponsor shall review the status of each device under his/her sponsorship to ensure it is still authorized to receive certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS shall describe procedures to ensure that certificate accountability is maintained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See section 9.6.3 for subscriber responsibilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before issuing a certificate with a wildcard character (\*) in a CN or subjectAltName of type DNS-ID, the CA shall establish and follow a documented procedure to ensure that the wildcard does not fall immediately to the left of an agency or organization name, but is qualified down to a unique application, server, or server farm under control of the sponsor’s organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The device sponsor shall demonstrate that the domain name requested is entirely within the name space to be covered by the wildcard certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The identity of the sponsor shall be authenticated by:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verification of digitally signed messages sent from the sponsor using a certificate issued under this policy; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - In-person or supervised remote registration by the sponsor, with the identity of the sponsor confirmed in accordance with the requirements of section 3.2.3.1.

groups.title: Authentication for Derived PIV Credentials Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, identity shall be verified in accordance with the requirements specified for issuing derived credentials in \[SP 800-157\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA or CA shall:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  Verify that the request for certificate issuance to the applicant was submitted by an authorized agency employee.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  Use the PKI-AUTH authentication mechanism from Section 6 of FIPS 201 to verify that the PIV Authentication certificate on the applicant’s PIV Card is valid and that the applicant is in possession of the corresponding private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3)  Maintain a copy of the applicant’s PIV Authentication certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Seven days after issuing the Derived credential, the issuer should recheck the revocation status of the PIV Authentication certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This step can detect use of a compromised PIV Card to obtain a derived credential

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, the applicant shall appear in person or via supervised remote to present the PIV Card and perform the PKI-AUTH authentication mechanism.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA shall perform a one-to-one comparison of the applicant against biometric data stored on the PIV Card, in accordance with \[SP 800-76\], and shall record and maintain the biometric sample used to validate the applicant.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In cases where a 1:1 biometric match against the biometrics available on the PIV Card or in the chain-of-trust, as defined in \[FIPS201\] is not possible:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  The applicant shall present a government-issued form of identification (e.g., a passport or driver’s license) in addition to the PIV Card, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  The RA shall examine the presented credentials for biometric data that can be linked to the applicant (e.g., a photograph on the credential itself or a securely linked photograph of the applicant), and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3)  The process documentation for the issuance of the certificate shall include the identity of the person performing the verification of the second (non-PIV) form of identification, a signed declaration by that person that he or she verified the identity of the applicant as required by the CPS using the format set forth at 28 U.S.C. 1746 (declaration under penalty of perjury), a unique identifying number from the second form of identification or a facsimile of the ID, a biometric of the applicant, and the date and time of the verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information that is not verified shall not be included in certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before issuing CA certificates or signature certificates that assert organizational authority, the CA shall validate the individual’s authority to act in the name of the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For pseudonymous certificates that identify subjects by their organizational roles, the CA shall validate that the individual either holds that role or has been delegated the authority to sign on behalf of the role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In accordance with section 3.2.3.2, all requests for device certificates in the name of an organization, shall be digitally signed by the sponsor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, the CPS shall specify a process by which an organization identifies the individuals who may request certificates that assert organizational authority.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an organization specifies, in writing, the individuals who may request a certificate, then the CA shall not accept any certificate requests that are outside this specification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall provide an Applicant with a list of the organization’s authorized certificate requesters upon the Applicant’s verified written request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note: Examples of signature certificates that assert organizational authority are code signing certificates and FIPS 201 id-PIV-content-signing certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall determine the interoperability criteria for CAs operating under this policy.

groups.title: 4.2 Identification and Authentication for Re-key Requests
4.3.0 Identification and Authentication for Routine Re-key
Identification and Authentication for Routine Re-key Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Routine Re-key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificate re-key shall follow the same procedures as initial certificate issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For re-key of subscriber certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, the department or agency shall verify that the Subscriber is eligible to have a PIV Card (i.e., PIV Card is not terminated).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For re-key of subscriber certificates issued under id-fpki-common-High, identity may be established through use of current signature key, except that identity shall be established through an in-person registration process at least once every three years from the time of initial registration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For policies other than id-fpki-common-High, a subscriber’s identity may be established through use of current signature key, except that identity shall be re-established through an in-person or supervised remote registration process at least once every nine years from the time of initial registration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, for re-key of subscriber certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, identity shall be established via mutual authentication between the issuer and the cryptographic module containing the current key, if the new key will be stored in the same cryptographic module as the current key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identity shall be established through the initial registration process if the new key will be stored in a different cryptographic module than the current key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For device certificates, identity may be established through the use of the device’s current signature key or the signature key of the device’s human sponsor, except that identity shall be established through the initial registration process at least once every nine years from the time of initial registration.

groups.title: 4.3.1 Identification and Authentication for Re-key after Revocation
Identification and Authentication for Re-key after Revocation Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Re-key after Revocation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of certificate revocation, issuance of a new certificate shall always require that the party go through the initial registration process per section 3.2 above.

groups.title: 4.3 Identification and Authentication for Revocation Request
Identification and Authentication for Revocation Request Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Revocation Request

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests must be authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests to revoke a certificate may be authenticated using that certificate's public key, regardless of whether or not the associated private key has been compromised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Certificate application process must provide sufficient information to:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Establish the applicant’s authorization (by the employing or sponsoring agency) to obtain a certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (per section 3.2.3)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Establish and record identity of the applicant.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (per section 3.2.3)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Obtain the applicant’s public key and verify the applicant’s possession of the private key for each certificate required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (per section 3.2.1)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verify any role or authorization information requested for inclusion in the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These steps may be performed in any order that is convenient for the PKI Authorities and applicants that does not defeat security, but all must be completed before certificate issuance.

groups.title: 5.1.0 Who Can Submit a Certificate Application

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An application for a CA certificate shall be submitted by an authorized representative of the applicant CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An application for a user (subscriber) certificate shall be submitted by either the applicant or a trusted agent.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An application for a device certificate shall be submitted by the human sponsor of the device.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A code signing certificate has an Extended Key Usage (EKU) containing a value of id-kp-codeSigning OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-kp 3 }(1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.3).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An application for a code signing certificate shall be submitted by an authorized representative of the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All communications among PKI Authorities supporting the certificate application and issuance process shall be authenticated and protected from modification; any electronic transmission of shared secrets shall be protected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Communications may be electronic or out-of-band.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where electronic communications are used, cryptographic mechanisms commensurate with the strength of the public/private key pair shall be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Out-of-band communications shall protect the confidentiality and integrity of the data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers are responsible for providing accurate information on their certificate applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information in certificate applications must be verified as accurate before certificates are issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PKI Authorities shall specify procedures to verify information in certificate applications.

groups.title: Performing Identification and Authentication Functions Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The identification and authentication of the subscriber must meet the requirements specified for subscriber authentication as specified in sections 3.2 and 3.3 of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The PKI Authority must identify the components of the PKI Authority (e.g., CA or RA) that are responsible for authenticating the subscriber’s identity in each case.

groups.title: 5.2.1 Approval or Rejection of Certificate Applications
Approval or Rejection of Certificate Applications Controls

controls.title: Approval or Rejection of Certificate Applications

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Common Policy Root CAs, the FPKIPA may approve or reject a certificate application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs operating under this policy, approval or rejection of certificate applications is at the discretion of the Agency PMA or its designee.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For Device certificates, the CA shall reject a certificate request if the requested Public Key has a known weak Private Key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public key parameters generation and quality checking, shall be conducted in accordance with NIST SP 800-89.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key validity shall be confirmed in accordance with NIST SP 800-56A.

groups.title: Time to Process Certificate Applications Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate applications must be processed and a certificate issued within 30 days of identity verification.

groups.title: CA Actions During Certificate Issuance Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Upon receiving the request, the CAs/RAs will—

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verify the identity of the requester.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verify the authority of the requester and the integrity of the information in the certificate request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Build and sign a certificate if all certificate requirements have been met (in the case of an RA, have the CA sign the certificate).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Make the certificate available to the subscriber after confirming that the subscriber has formally acknowledged their obligations as described in section 9.6.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The certificate request may already contain a certificate built by either the RA or the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This certificate will not be signed until all verifications and modifications, if any, have been completed to the CA’s satisfaction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All authorization and other attribute information received from a prospective subscriber shall be verified before inclusion in a certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The responsibility for verifying prospective subscriber data shall be described in a CA’s CPS.

groups.title: 5.3.1 Notification to Subscriber by the CA of Issuance of Certificate
Notification to Subscriber by the CA of Issuance of Certificate Controls

controls.title: Notification to Subscriber by the CA of Issuance of Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy shall inform the subscriber (or other certificate subject) of the creation of a certificate and make the certificate available to the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For device certificates, the CA shall inform the human sponsor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before a subscriber can make effective use of its private key, a PKI Authority shall explain to the subscriber its responsibilities as defined in section 9.6.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Common Policy Root CA, failure to object to the certificate or its contents shall constitute acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.4.1 Publication of the Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in 2.1, all CA certificates shall be published in repositories.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of subscriber certificates, except as noted in section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.4.2 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Whenever a CA operating under this policy issues a CA certificate, the FPKIPA shall be notified at least two weeks prior to issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, all new artifacts (CA certificates, CRL DP, AIA and/or SIA URLs, etc.) produced as a result of the event shall be provided to the FPKIPA within 24 hours following issuance.

groups.title: 5.5.0 Subscriber Private Key and Certificate Usage
Subscriber Private Key and Certificate Usage Controls

controls.title: Subscriber Private Key and Certificate Usage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The intended scope of usage for a private key is specified through certificate extensions, including the key usage and extended key usage extensions, in the associated certificate.

groups.title: 5.5.1 Relying Party Public key and Certificate Usage
Relying Party Public key and Certificate Usage Controls

controls.title: Relying Party Public key and Certificate Usage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Common Policy-issued certificates specify restrictions on use through critical certificate extensions, including the basic constraints and key usage extensions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CAs operating under this policy shall issue CRLs specifying the current status of all unexpired certificates (except for OCSP responder certificates that include the id-pkix-ocsp-nocheck extension).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: It is recommended that relying parties process and comply with this information whenever using Common Policy certificates in a transaction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Renewing a certificate means creating a new certificate with the same name, key, and other information as the old one, but with a new, extended validity period and a new serial number.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The old certificate may or may not be revoked, but must not be further re-keyed, renewed, or modified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates issued under this policy shall not be renewed, except during recovery from CA key compromise (see 5.7.3).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In such cases, the renewed certificate shall expire as specified in the original subscriber certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA Certificates and OCSP responder certificates may be renewed so long as the aggregated lifetime of the public key does not exceed the certificate lifetime specified in section 6.3.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA may automatically renew certificates during recovery from key compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all CAs and OCSP responders operating under this policy, the corresponding operating authority may request renewal of its own certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Common Policy Root CA, the FPKIMA may also request renewal of CA certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Common Policy Root CA, CA certificate renewal for reasons other than re-key of the Common Policy Root CA shall be approved by the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other renewal requests, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.6.3 Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber
Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber Controls

controls.title: Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall inform the subscriber of the renewal of his or her certificate and the contents of the certificate.

groups.title: 5.6.4 Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Renewal Certificate
Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Renewal Certificate Controls

controls.title: Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Renewal Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued by the Common Policy Root CA, failure to object to the renewal of the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.6.5 Publication of the Renewal Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Renewal Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Renewal Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in section 2.1, all CA certificates shall be published in repositories.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of subscriber certificates, except as noted in section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.6.6 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Re-keying a certificate consists of creating new certificates with a different public key (and serial number) while retaining the remaining contents of the old certificate that describe the subject.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new certificate may be assigned a different validity period, key identifiers, specify a different CRL distribution point, and/or be signed with a different key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Re-key of a certificate does not require a change to the subjectName and does not violate the requirement for name uniqueness.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The old certificate may or may not be revoked, but must not be further re-keyed, renewed, or modified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers shall identify themselves for the purpose of re-keying as required in section 3.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The longer and more often a key is used, the more susceptible it is to loss or discovery.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Therefore, it is important that a subscriber periodically obtain new keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Section 6.3.2 establishes usage periods for private keys for both CAs and subscribers.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples of circumstances requiring certificate re-key include: expiration, loss or compromise, issuance of a new hardware token, and hardware token failure.

groups.title: 5.7.1 Who May Request Certification of a New Public Key
Who May Request Certification of a New Public Key Controls

controls.title: Who May Request Certification of a New Public Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests for certification of a new public key shall be considered as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers with a currently valid certificate may request certification of a new public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs and RAs may request certification of a new public key on behalf of a subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For device certificates, the human sponsor of the device may request certification of a new public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Digital signatures on subscriber re-key requests shall be validated before electronic re-key requests are processed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Alternatively, subscriber re-key requests may be processed using the same process used for initial certificate issuance.

groups.title: 5.7.3 Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber
Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber Controls

controls.title: Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Re-keyed Certificate Controls

controls.title: Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Re-keyed Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued by the Common Policy Root CA, failure to object to the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.7.5 Publication of the Re-keyed Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Re-keyed Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Re-keyed Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CA certificates must be published as specified in section 2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of subscriber certificates, except as noted in section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.7.6 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Modifying a certificate means creating a new certificate that has the same or a different key and a different serial number, and that differs in one or more other fields from the old certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The old certificate may or may not be revoked, but must not be further re-keyed, renewed, or modified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA operating under this policy may modify a CA or OCSP responder certificate whose characteristics have changed (e.g. assert new policy OID).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new certificate may have the same or a different subject public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA may perform certificate modification for a subscriber whose characteristics have changed (e.g., name change due to marriage).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new certificate shall have a different subject public key.

groups.title: Who May Request Certificate Modification Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests for certification of a new public key shall be considered as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers with a currently valid certificate may request certificate modification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs and RAs may request certificate modification on behalf of a subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For device certificates, the human sponsor of the device may request certificate modification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an individual’s name changes (e.g., due to marriage), then proof of the name change must be provided to the RA or other designated agent in order for a certificate with the new name to be issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an individual’s authorizations or privileges change, the RA will verify those authorizations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If authorizations have reduced, the old certificate must be revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Proof of all subject information changes must be provided to the RA or other designated agent and verified before the modified certificate is issued.

groups.title: 5.8.3 Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber
Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber Controls

controls.title: Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

Conduct Constituting Acceptance of Modified Certificate Controls

controls.title: Conduct Constituting Acceptance of Modified Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued by the Common Policy Root CA, failure to object to the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation

Publication of the Modified Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Modified Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CA certificates must be published as specified in section 2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of subscriber certificates, except as noted in section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.8.6 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy shall issue CRLs covering all unexpired certificates issued under this policy except for OCSP responder certificates that include the id-pkix-ocsp-nocheck extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy shall make public a description of how to obtain revocation information for the certificates they publish, and an explanation of the consequences of using dated revocation information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This information shall be given to subscribers during certificate request or issuance, and shall be readily available to any potential relying party.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests must be authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests to revoke a certificate may be authenticated using that certificate's associated private key, regardless of whether or not the private key has been compromised***.***

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate suspension for CA certificates is not allowed by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: However, the use of certificate suspension for end entity certificates is allowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs operating under this policy, the FPKIPA shall be notified at least two weeks prior to the revocation of a CA certificate, whenever possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For emergency revocation, CAs shall follow the notification procedures in Section 5.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A certificate shall be revoked when the binding between the subject and the subject’s public key defined within the certificate is no longer considered valid.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples of circumstances that invalidate the binding are—

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Identifying information or affiliation components of any names in the certificate becomes invalid.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This would include evidence that a wild card certificate has been issued with a name where PKI Sponsor does not exercise control of the entire name space associated with the wild card certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Privilege attributes asserted in the subscriber’s certificate are reduced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The subscriber can be shown to have violated the stipulations of its subscriber agreement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - There is reason to believe the private key has been compromised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The subscriber or other authorized party (as defined in the CPS) asks for his/her certificate to be revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The failure of a CA to adequately adhere to the requirements of this CP or the approved CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For example, there is strong evidence that the CA has failed to comply with the requirements of section 6.7 of the CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If it is determined that revocation is required, the associated certificate shall be revoked and placed on the CRL.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revoked certificates shall be included on all new publications of the certificate status information until the certificates expire.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If it is determined that a private key used to authorize the issuance of one or more certificates may have been compromised, all certificates directly or indirectly authorized by that private key since the date of actual or suspected compromise shall be revoked or shall be verified as appropriately issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Within the PKI, a CA may summarily revoke certificates within its domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A written notice and brief explanation for the revocation shall subsequently be provided to the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA can request the revocation of a subscriber’s certificate on behalf of any authorized party as specified in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A subscriber may request that its own certificate be revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The human sponsor of a device can request the revocation of the device’s certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Other authorized agency officials may request revocation as described in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall provide Subscribers, Relying Parties, Application Software Suppliers, and other third parties with clear instructions for reporting suspected Private Key Compromise, Certificate misuse, or other types of fraud, compromise, misuse, inappropriate conduct, or any other matter related to Certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall publicly disclose the instructions through a readily accessible online means.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A request to revoke a certificate shall identify the certificate to be revoked, explain the reason for revocation, and allow the request to be authenticated (e.g., digitally or manually signed).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The steps involved in the process of requesting a certification revocation are detailed in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where subscribers use hardware tokens, revocation is optional if all the following conditions are met:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the revocation request was not for key compromise;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the hardware token does not permit the user to export the signature private key;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the subscriber surrendered the token to the PKI;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the token was zeroized or destroyed promptly upon surrender;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the token has been protected from malicious use between surrender and zeroization or destruction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In all other cases, revocation of the certificates is mandatory.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Even where all the above conditions have been met, revocation of the associated certificates is recommended.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is no grace period for revocation under this policy.

groups.title: 5.9.4 Time within which CA must Process the Revocation Request
Time within which CA must Process the Revocation Request Controls

controls.title: Time within which CA must Process the Revocation Request

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs will revoke certificates as quickly as practical upon receipt of a proper revocation request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests shall be processed before the next CRL is published, excepting those requests received within two hours of CRL issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests received within two hours of CRL issuance shall be processed before the following CRL is published.

groups.title: 5.9.5 Revocation Checking Requirements for Relying Parties
Revocation Checking Requirements for Relying Parties Controls

controls.title: Revocation Checking Requirements for Relying Parties

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice note: Use of revoked certificates could have damaging or catastrophic consequences.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The matter of how often new revocation data should be obtained is a determination to be made by the relying party, considering the risk, responsibility, and consequences for using a certificate whose revocation status cannot be guaranteed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CRLs shall be issued periodically, even if there are no changes to be made, to ensure timeliness of information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate status information may be issued more frequently than the issuance frequency described below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate status information shall be published not later than the next scheduled update.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This will facilitate the local caching of certificate status information for off-line or remote (laptop) operation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating as part of the Shared Service Providers program that only issue certificates to CAs and that operate off-line must issue CRLs at least once every 24 hours, and the *nextUpdate* time in the CRL may be no later than 48 hours after issuance time (i.e., the *thisUpdate* time).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legacy Federal PKIs, root CAs, and the Common Policy Root CA that only issue certificates to CAs and that operate off-line must issue CRLs at least once every 31 days, and the *nextUpdate* time in the CRL may be no later than 32 days after issuance time (i.e., the *thisUpdate* time).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that issue certificates to subscribers or operate on-line must issue CRLs at least once every 18 hours, and the *nextUpdate* time in the CRL may be no later than 48 hours after issuance time (i.e., the *thisUpdate* time).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For legacy Federal PKIs only, the *nextUpdate* time in the CRL may be no later than 180 hours after issuance time (i.e., the *thisUpdate* time).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note: Since many applications only check for a new CRL at nextUpdate, a longer nextUpdate time may result in applications continuing to rely on older CRLs even when a newer CRL is available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A longer nextUpdate time also increases the potential of a replay attack to validate a newly revoked certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the CRL nextUpdate exceeds 48 hours, relying parties should consider these risks and take appropriate measures to mitigate the risk.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For high-risk, sensitive Relying Party applications suggested measures include configuring a preference for OCSP by applications, pre-fetching CRLs at least every 18 hours, and use of other compensating controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Circumstances related to emergency CRL issuance are specified in section 4.9.12.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CRLs shall be published within 4 hours of generation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Furthermore, each CRL shall be published no later than the time specified in the *nextUpdate* field of the previously issued CRL for same scope.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs shall support on-line status checking via OCSP \[RFC 6960\] for end entity certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, id-fpki-common-cardAuth, and id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where on-line status checking is supported, status information must be updated and available to relying parties within 18 hours of certificate revocation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where on-line status checking is supported and a certificate issued under id-fpki-common-High is revoked for key compromise, the status information must be updated and available to relying parties within 6 hours.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall operate and maintain its CRL and OCSP capability with resources sufficient to provide a response time of ten seconds or less under normal operating conditions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall maintain an online 24x7 Repository that application software can use to automatically check the current status of all unexpired Certificates issued by the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall maintain a continuous 24x7 ability to respond internally to a high-priority Certificate Problem Report, and where appropriate, forward such a complaint to law enforcement authorities, and/or revoke a Certificate that is the subject of such a complaint.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Since some relying parties cannot accommodate on-line communications, all CAs will be required to support CRLs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Relying party client software may optionally support on-line status checking.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Client software using on-line status checking need not obtain or process CRLs.
