groups.title: 5.12.0 Key Escrow and Recovery Policy and Practices
Key Escrow and Recovery Policy and Practices Controls

controls.title: Key Escrow and Recovery Policy and Practices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private keys are never escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Human subscriber key management keys shall be escrowed to provide key recovery.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs shall develop a Key Recovery Practice Statement (KRPS) describing the procedures and controls implemented to comply with the *FPKI Key Recovery Policy*.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRPS may be a separate document or may be combined with the appropriate Certification Practice Statement and/or Registration Practice Statement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Federal PKI Policy Authority (FPKIPA) will determine the KRPS compliance with the KRP and this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Under no circumstances shall a subscriber signature key be held in trust by a third party.

groups.title: 5.12.1 Session Key Encapsulation and Recovery Policy and Practices
Session Key Encapsulation and Recovery Policy and Practices Controls

controls.title: Session Key Encapsulation and Recovery Policy and Practices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that support session key encapsulation and recovery shall identify the document describing the practices in the applicable CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA equipment shall be protected from unauthorized access while the cryptographic module is installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall implement physical access controls to reduce the risk of equipment tampering even when the cryptographic module is not installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA cryptographic tokens shall be protected against theft, loss, and unauthorized use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All the physical control requirements specified below apply equally to the Common Policy Root CA and subordinate CAs, and any remote workstations used to administer the CAs except where specifically noted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The location and construction of the facility housing the CA equipment, as well as sites housing remote workstations used to administer the CAs, shall be consistent with facilities used to house high-value, sensitive information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The site location and construction, when combined with other physical security protection mechanisms such as guards, high security locks, and intrusion sensors, shall provide robust protection against unauthorized access to the CA equipment and records.

groups.title: Physical Access for CA Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the physical access controls for CA equipment, as well as remote workstations used to administer the CAs, shall—

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensure that no unauthorized access to the hardware is permitted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensure that all removable media and paper containing sensitive plain-text information is stored in secure containers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Be manually or electronically monitored for unauthorized intrusion at all times.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensure an access log is maintained and inspected periodically.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Require two-person physical access control to both the cryptographic module and computer systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When not in use, removable cryptographic modules, activation information used to access or enable cryptographic modules, and CA equipment shall be placed in secure containers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Activation data shall be either memorized or recorded and stored in a manner commensurate with the security afforded the cryptographic module, and shall not be stored with the cryptographic module or removable hardware associated with remote workstations used to administer the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A security check of the facility housing the CA equipment or remote workstations used to administer the CAs shall occur if the facility is to be left unattended.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the check shall verify the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The equipment is in a state appropriate to the current mode of operation (e.g., that cryptographic modules are in place when “open,” and secured when “closed,” and for the CA, that all equipment other than the repository is shut down).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any security containers are properly secured.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Physical security systems (e.g., door locks, vent covers) are functioning properly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The area is secured against unauthorized access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A person or group of persons shall be made explicitly responsible for making such checks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a group of persons is responsible, a log identifying the person performing a check at each instance shall be maintained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the facility is not continuously attended, the last person to depart shall initial a sign-out sheet that indicates the date and time and asserts that all necessary physical protection mechanisms are in place and activated.

groups.title: Physical Access for RA Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA equipment shall be protected from unauthorized access while the cryptographic module is installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA shall implement physical access controls to reduce the risk of equipment tampering even when the cryptographic module is not installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These security mechanisms shall be commensurate with the level of threat in the RA equipment environment.

groups.title: Physical Access for CSS Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical access control requirements for CSS equipment (if implemented), shall meet the CA physical access requirements specified in 5.1.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall have backup capability sufficient to lock out input, finish any pending actions, and record the state of the equipment automatically before lack of power or air conditioning causes a shutdown.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The repositories (containing CA certificates and CRLs) shall be provided with uninterrupted power sufficient for a minimum of 6 hours operation in the absence of commercial power, to maintain availability and avoid denial of service.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA equipment shall be installed such that it is not in danger of exposure to water (e.g., on tables or elevated floors).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Potential water damage from fire prevention and protection measures (e.g., sprinkler systems) are excluded from this requirement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media shall be stored so as to protect them from accidental damage (e.g., water, fire, or electromagnetic) and unauthorized physical access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Sensitive media and documentation that are no longer needed for operations shall be destroyed in a secure manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For example, sensitive paper documentation shall be shredded, burned, or otherwise rendered unrecoverable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Full system backups sufficient to recover from system failure shall be made on a periodic schedule, and described in a CA’s CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups are to be performed and stored off-site not less than once per week.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one full backup copy shall be stored at an off-site location (separate from CA equipment).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only the latest full backup need be retained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The backup shall be stored at a site with physical and procedural controls commensurate to that of the operational CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For legacy Federal PKIs operating an offline CA, the full system backup shall be performed each time the system is turned on or once a week, whichever is less frequent.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requirements for CA private key backup are specified in section 6.2.4.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A trusted role is one whose incumbent performs functions that can introduce security problems if not carried out properly, whether accidentally or maliciously.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The people selected to fill these roles must be extraordinarily responsible, or the integrity of the CA will be weakened.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The functions performed in these roles form the basis of trust for the entire PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Two approaches are taken to increase the likelihood that these roles can be successfully carried out.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The first ensures that the person filling the role is trustworthy and properly trained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The second distributes the functions among more than one person, so that any malicious activity would require collusion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements of this policy are defined in terms of four roles.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Note: the information derives from the Certificate Issuing and Management Components (CIMC) Protection Profile.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  *Administrator* – authorized to install, configure, and maintain the CA; establish and maintain system accounts; configure audit parameters; and generate component keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  *Officer* – authorized to request or approve certificate issuance and revocations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  *Auditor* – authorized to review, maintain, and archive audit logs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4.  *Operator* – authorized to perform system backup and recovery.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Administrators do not issue certificates to subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The roles required for each level of assurance are identified in Section 5.2.4.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These four roles are employed at the CA, RA, and CSS locations as appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Separation of duties shall comply with 5.2.4, and requirements for two person control with 5.2.2, regardless of the titles and numbers of Trusted Roles.

groups.title: 6.2.1 Number of Persons Required per Task
Number of Persons Required per Task Controls

controls.title: Number of Persons Required per Task

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Two or more persons are required for the following tasks:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA key generation;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA signing key activation;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA private key backup.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where multiparty control is required, at least one of the participants shall be an Administrator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All participants must serve in a trusted role as defined in section 5.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multiparty control shall not be achieved using personnel that serve in the Auditor trusted role.

groups.title: 6.2.2 Identification and Authentication for Each Role
Identification and Authentication for Each Role Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Each Role

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An individual shall identify and authenticate him/herself before being permitted to perform any actions set forth above for that role or identity.

groups.title: Roles Requiring Separation of Duties Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals may only assume one of the Officer, Administrator, and Auditor roles, but any individual may assume the Operator role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA and RA software and hardware shall identify and authenticate its users and shall ensure that no user identity can assume both the Administrator and Officer roles, assume both the Administrator and Auditor roles, or assume both the Auditor and Officer roles.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that issue at id-fpki-common-High, the Auditor may not assume any other role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No individual shall have more than one identity.

groups.title: Qualifications, Experience, and Clearance Requirements Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All persons filling trusted roles shall be selected on the basis of loyalty, trustworthiness, and integrity, and must be U.S. citizens.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements governing the qualifications, selection and oversight of individuals who operate, manage, oversee, and audit the CA shall be set forth in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA personnel shall, at a minimum, pass a background investigation covering the following areas:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Employment;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Education;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Place of residence;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Law Enforcement; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - References.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The period of investigation must cover at least the last five years for each area, excepting the residence check which must cover at least the last three years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Regardless of the date of award, the highest educational degree shall be verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Adjudication of the background investigation shall be performed by a competent adjudication authority using a process consistent with Executive Order 12968 August 1995, or equivalent.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All personnel performing duties with respect to the operation of the CA or RA shall receive comprehensive training.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Training shall be conducted in the following areas:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA (or RA) security principles and mechanisms;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All PKI software versions in use on the CA (or RA) system;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All PKI duties they are expected to perform;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Disaster recovery and business continuity procedures; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Stipulations of this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All individuals responsible for PKI roles shall be made aware of changes in the CA operation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any significant change to the operations shall have a training (awareness) plan, and the execution of such plan shall be documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples of such changes are CA software or hardware upgrade, changes in automated security systems, and relocation of equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Documentation shall be maintained identifying all personnel who received training and the level of training completed.

groups.title: Job Rotation Frequency and Sequence Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall take appropriate administrative and disciplinary actions against personnel who have performed actions involving the CA or its RAs that are not authorized in this CP, CPSs, or other published procedures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Contractors fulfilling trusted roles are subject to all personnel requirements stipulated in this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PKI vendors who provide any services shall establish procedures to ensure that any subcontractors perform in accordance with this policy and the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Documentation sufficient to define duties and procedures for each role shall be provided to the personnel filling that role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit log files shall be generated for all events relating to the security of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs operated in a virtual machine environment (VME)[^2], audit logs shall be generated for all applicable events on both the virtual machine (VM) and isolation kernel (i.e. hypervisor).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where possible, the security audit logs shall be automatically collected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where this is not possible, a logbook, paper form, or other physical mechanism shall be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All security audit logs, both electronic and non-electronic, shall be retained and made available during compliance audits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All security auditing capabilities of CA operating system and CA applications required by this CP shall be enabled during installation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, each audit record shall include the following (either recorded automatically or manually for each auditable event):

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The type of event;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The date and time the event occurred;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A success or failure indicator when executing the CA’s signing process;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A success or failure indicator when performing certificate revocation; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The identity of the entity and/or operator that caused the event.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A message from any source requesting an action by the CA is an auditable event; the corresponding audit record must also include message date and time, source, destination, and contents.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA shall record the events identified in the list below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where these events cannot be electronically logged, the CA shall supplement electronic audit logs with physical logs as necessary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - SECURITY AUDIT:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any changes to the Audit parameters, e.g., audit frequency, type of event audited

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any attempt to delete or modify the Audit logs

parts.prose: For CAs that issue certificates under id-fpki-common-High, review of the audit log shall be required at least once every month.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that do not issue certificates under id-fpki-common-High, review of the audit log shall be required at least once every two months.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such reviews involve verifying that the log has not been tampered with and then briefly inspecting all log entries, with a more thorough investigation of any alerts or irregularities in the logs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A statistically significant portion of the security audit data generated by the CA since the last review shall be examined.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This amount will be described in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All significant events shall be explained in an audit log summary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Actions taken as a result of these reviews shall be documented.

groups.title: Retention Period for Audit Log Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit logs shall be retained on-site until reviewed, in addition to being archived as described in section 5.5.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The individual who removes audit logs from the CA system shall be an official different from the individuals who, in combination, command the CA signature key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The security audit data shall not be open for reading or modification by any human, or by any automated process, other than those that perform security audit processing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA system configuration and procedures must be implemented together to ensure that only authorized people archive or delete security audit data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures must be implemented to protect archived data from deletion or destruction before the end of the security audit data retention period (note that deletion requires modification access).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security audit data shall be moved to a safe, secure storage location separate from the location where the data was generated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit logs and audit summaries shall be backed up at least monthly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A copy of the audit log shall be sent off-site on a monthly basis.

groups.title: Audit Collection System (Internal vs. External) Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The audit log collection system may or may not be external to the CA system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Automated audit processes shall be invoked at system or application startup, and cease only at system or application shutdown.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit collection systems shall be configured such that security audit data is protected against loss (e.g., overwriting or overflow of automated log files).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Should it become apparent that an automated audit system has failed, and the integrity of the system or confidentiality of the information protected by the system is at risk, operations shall be suspended until the problem has been remedied.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is no requirement to notify a subject that an event was audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Real-time alerts are neither required nor prohibited by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA will perform routine self-assessments of security controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The security audit data should be reviewed by the security auditor for events such as repeated failed actions, requests for privileged information, attempted access of system files, and unauthenticated responses.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security auditors should check for continuity of the security audit data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To minimize risk from compromise of a CA’s private signing key, that key may be changed often.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: From that time on, only the new key will be used to sign CA and subscriber certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the old private key is used to sign OCSP responder certificates or CRLs that cover certificates signed with that key, the old key must be retained and protected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: After a CA performs a Key Changeover, the CA may continue to issue CRLs with the old key until all certificates signed with that key have expired.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As an alternative, after all certificates signed with that old key have been revoked, the CA may issue a final long-term CRL using the old key, with a nextUpdate time past the validity period of all issued certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This final CRL shall be available for all relying parties until the validity period of all issued certificates has past.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once the last CRL has been issued, the old private signing key of the CA may be destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA’s signing key shall have a validity period as described in section 6.3.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA updates its private signature key and thus generates a new public key, the CA shall notify all CAs, RAs, and subscribers that rely on the CA’s certificate that it has been changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA that distributes self-signed certificates updates its private signature key, the CA shall generate key rollover certificates, where the new public key is signed by the old private key, and vice versa.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This permits acceptance of newly issued certificates and CRLs without distribution of the new self-signed certificate to current users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key rollover certificates are optional for CAs that do not distribute self-signed certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SSPs and Federal Legacy PKIs CAs cross certified with the Common Policy Root CA must be able to continue to interoperate with the Common Policy Root CA after the Common Policy Root CA performs a key rollover, whether or not the DN of the Common Policy Root CA is changed.

groups.title: Incident and Compromise Handling Procedures Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall be notified if any CAs operating under this policy experience the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - suspected or detected compromise of the CA systems;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - suspected or detected compromise of a certificate status server (CSS) if (1) the CSS certificate has a lifetime of more than 72 hours and (2) the CSS certificate cannot be revoked (e.g., an OCSP responder certificate with the id-pkix-ocsp-nocheck extension);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - physical or electronic penetration of CA systems;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - successful denial of service attacks on CA components; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - any incident preventing the CA from issuing a CRL within 48 hours of the issuance of the previous CRL.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will take appropriate steps to protect the integrity of the Federal PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA’s Management Authority shall reestablish operational capabilities as quickly as possible in accordance with procedures set forth in the CA's CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of an incident as described above, the organization operating the CA shall notify the FPKIPA within 24 hours of incident discovery, along with preliminary remediation analysis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Within 10 business days of incident resolution, the organization operating the CA shall post a notice on its publically available web page identifying the incident and provide notification to the FPKIPA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The public notice shall include the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  Which CA components were affected by the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  The CA's interpretation of the incident.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  Who is impacted by the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4.  When the incident was discovered

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 5.  A complete list of all certificates that were either issued erroneously or not compliant with the CP/CPS as a result of the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 6.  A statement that the incident has been fully remediated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The notification provided directly to the FPKIPA shall also include detailed measures taken to remediate the incident.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will post the notices to idmanagement.gov and provide an announcement to all Federal Agencies and Bridge Affiliate PKIs.

groups.title: 6.7.1 Computing Resources, Software, and/or Data Are Corrupted
Computing Resources, Software, and/or Data Are Corrupted Controls

controls.title: Computing Resources, Software, and/or Data Are Corrupted

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When computing resources, software, and/or data are corrupted, CAs operating under this policy shall respond as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Before returning to operation, ensure that the system’s integrity has been restored.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - If the CA signature keys are not destroyed**,** CA operation shall be reestablished, giving priority to the ability to generate certificate status information within the CRL issuance schedule specified in section 4.9.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - If the CA signature keys are destroyed**,** CA operation shall be reestablished as quickly as possible, giving priority to the generation of a new CA key pair.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Agency PMA shall be notified as soon as possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of an incident as described above, the organization operating the CA shall post a notice on its web page identifying the incident and provide notification to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 5.7.1 for contents of the notice.

groups.title: Entity (CA) Private Key Compromise Procedures Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of a CA private key compromise, the following operations must be performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The FPKIPA shall be immediately informed, as well as any superior or cross-certified CAs and any entities known to be distributing the CA certificate (e.g., in a root store).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA must generate new keys in accordance with section 6.1.1.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the CA distributed the private key in a Trusted Certificate, the CA shall perform the following operations:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Generate a new Trusted Certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Securely distribute the new Trusted Certificate as specified in section 6.1.4.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Initiate procedures to notify subscribers of the compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates may be renewed automatically by the CA under the new key pair (see section 4.6), or the CA may require subscribers to repeat the initial certificate application process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization operating the CA shall post a notice on its web page describing the compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 5.7.1 for contents of the notice.

groups.title: 6.7.3 Business Continuity Capabilities after a Disaster
Business Continuity Capabilities after a Disaster Controls

controls.title: Business Continuity Capabilities after a Disaster

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Common Policy Root CA, recovery procedures shall be in place to reconstitute the CA within six (6) hours of failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All other CAs operating under this policy shall have recovery procedures in place to reconstitute the CA within 72 hours of failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case of a disaster whereby the CA installation is physically damaged and all copies of the CA signature key are destroyed as a result, the FPKIPA shall be notified at the earliest feasible time, and the FPKIPA shall take whatever action it deems appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Relying parties may decide of their own volition whether to continue to use certificates signed with the destroyed private key pending reestablishment of CA operation with new certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Whenever possible, the FPKIPA shall be notified at least two weeks prior to the termination of a CA operating under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For emergency termination, CAs shall follow the notification procedures in Section 5.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA operating under this policy terminates operations before all certificates have expired, the CA signing keys shall be surrendered to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This section does not apply to CAs that have ceased issuing new certificates but are continuing to issue CRLs until all certificates have expired.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such CAs are required to continue to conform with all relevant aspects of this policy (e.g., audit logging and archives).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any issued certificates that have not expired, shall be revoked and a final long term CRL with a nextUpdate time past the validity period of all issued certificates shall be generated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This final CRL shall be available for all relying parties until the validity period of all issued certificates has past.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once the last CRL has been issued, the private signing key(s) of the CA to be terminated will be destroyed or taken offline, designated as “not in use”, and protected as stipulated in 5.1.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Prior to CA termination, the CA shall provide archived data to an archive facility as specified in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As soon as possible, the CA will advise all other organizations to which it has issued certificates of its termination, using an agreed-upon method of communication specified in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic keying material used by CAs to sign certificates, CRLs or status information shall be generated in FIPS 140 validated cryptographic modules.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that issue certificates under id-fpki-common-High, the module(s) shall meet or exceed FIPS 140 Level 3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that do not issue certificates under id-fpki-common-High, the module(s) shall meet or exceed FIPS 140 Level 2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multiparty control is required for CA key pair generation, as specified in section 6.2.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA key pair generation must create a verifiable audit trail that the security requirements for procedures were followed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The documentation of the procedure must be detailed enough to show that appropriate role separation was used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An independent third party shall validate the execution of the key generation procedures either by witnessing the key generation or by examining the signed and documented record of the key generation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the audit trail identifies and documents any failures or anomalies in the key generation process, along with the corrective action taken, the key generation process need not be restarted but may continue.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber key pair generation may be performed by the subscriber, CA, or RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the CA or RA generates subscriber key pairs, the requirements for key pair delivery specified in section 6.1.2 must also be met.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Validated software or hardware cryptographic modules shall be used to generate all subscriber key pairs, as well as pseudo-random numbers and parameters used in key pair generation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the id‑fpki-common-hardware, id-fpki-common-High, id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth, and id-fpki-common-cardauth policies, subscriber key pairs shall be generated in FIPS 140 Level 2 hardware cryptographic modules.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any pseudo-random numbers used for key generation material shall be generated by a FIPS-approved method.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Symmetric keys may be generated by means of either software or hardware mechanisms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the audit trail identifies and documents any failures or anomalies in the key generation process, along with the corrective action taken, the key generation process need not be restarted but may continue.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic keying material used by CSSes to sign status information shall be generated in FIPS 140 validated cryptographic modules.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CSSes that provide status under id-fpki-common-High, the module(s) shall meet or exceed FIPS 140 Level 3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CSSes that do not provide status under id-fpki-common-High, the module(s) shall meet or exceed FIPS 140 Level 2.

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement

groups.title: Private Key Delivery to Subscriber Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If subscribers generate their own key pairs, then there is no need to deliver private keys, and this section does not apply.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When CAs or RAs generate keys on behalf of the subscriber, then the private key must be delivered securely to the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Private keys may be delivered electronically or may be delivered on a hardware cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In all cases, the following requirements must be met:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Anyone who generates a private signing key for a subscriber shall not retain any copy of the key after delivery of the private key to the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The private key(s) must be protected from activation, compromise, or modification during the delivery process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The subscriber shall acknowledge receipt of the private key(s).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Delivery shall be accomplished in a way that ensures that the correct tokens and activation data are provided to the correct subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - For hardware modules, accountability for the location and state of the module must be maintained until the subscriber accepts possession of it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - For electronic delivery of private keys, the key material shall be encrypted using a cryptographic algorithm and key size at least as strong as the private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Activation data shall be delivered using a separate secure channel.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must maintain a record of the subscriber acknowledgment of receipt of the token.

groups.title: 7.1.2 Public Key Delivery to Certificate Issuer
Public Key Delivery to Certificate Issuer Controls

controls.title: Public Key Delivery to Certificate Issuer

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where key pairs are generated by the subscriber or RA, the public key and the subscriber’s identity must be delivered securely to the CA for certificate issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The delivery mechanism shall bind the subscriber’s verified identity to the public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If cryptography is used to achieve this binding, it must be at least as strong as the CA keys used to sign the certificate.

groups.title: 7.1.3 CA Public Key Delivery to Relying Parties
CA Public Key Delivery to Relying Parties Controls

controls.title: CA Public Key Delivery to Relying Parties

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA updates its signature key pair, the CA shall distribute the new public key in a secure fashion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new public key may be distributed in a self-signed certificate, in a key rollover certificate, or in cross-certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Self-signed certificates shall be conveyed to relying parties in a secure fashion to preclude substitution attacks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Acceptable methods for self-signed certificate delivery are:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Loading a self-signed certificate onto tokens delivered to relying parties via secure mechanisms; such as

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The Trusted Certificate is loaded onto the token during the subscriber’s appearance at the RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The Trusted Certificate is loaded onto the token when the RA generates the subscriber’s key pair and loads the private key onto the token, which is then delivered to the subscriber in accordance with section 6.1.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Secure distribution of self-signed certificates through secure out-of-band mechanisms;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Comparison of the hash of the self-signed certificate against a hash value made available via authenticated out-of-band sources (note that hashes posted in-band along with the certificate are not acceptable as an authentication mechanism); and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Loading certificates from web sites secured with a currently valid certificate of equal or greater assurance level than the certificate being downloaded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key rollover certificates are signed with the CA’s current private key, so secure distribution is not required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To ensure the availability of the new public key, the key rollover certificates must be distributed using repositories.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note: Other methods that preclude substitution attacks may be considered acceptable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP requires use of RSA PKCS \#1, RSASSA-PSS, or ECDSA signatures; additional restrictions on key sizes and hash algorithms are detailed below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this policy shall contain RSA or elliptic curve public keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note: Future versions of this policy may specify additional FIPS-approved signature algorithms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Trusted Certificates that expire before January 1, 2031 shall contain subject public keys of 2048 or 3072 bits for RSA or 256 or 384 bits for elliptic curve, and be signed with the corresponding private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Trusted Certificates that expire on or after January 1, 2031 shall contain subject public keys of at least 3072 bits for RSA or 256 or 384 bits for elliptic curve, and be signed with the corresponding private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Where certificates are issued to satisfy FIPS 201 requirements, CAs shall use signature keys of 2048 or 3072 or 4096 bits for RSA and 256 or 384 bits for elliptic curve algorithms to sign certificates issued on or after January 1, 2008. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that generate certificates and CRLs under this policy shall use signature keys of 1024, 2048, 3072, or 4096 bits for RSA and 256 or 384 bits for elliptic curve algorithms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that expire on or after December 31, 2010 shall be generated with 2048 or 3072 bit keys for RSA and 256 or 384 bit keys for elliptic curve algorithms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that expire after December 31, 2030 shall be generated with at least 3072 bit keys for RSA and 256 or 384 bit keys for elliptic curve algorithms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that generate certificates and CRLs under this policy shall use the SHA-1, SHA‑256, or SHA-384 hash algorithm when generating digital signatures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RSA signatures on certificates and CRLs that are issued after December 31, 2010 shall be generated using SHA‑256 however, RSA signatures on CRLs that are issued before January 1, 2012, and that include status information for certificates that were generated using SHA-1 may be generated using SHA-1. RSA signatures on CRLs that are issued on or after January 1, 2012, but before January 1, 2014 that only provide status information for certificates that were generated using SHA-1 may continue to be generated using SHA-1. ECDSA signatures on certificates and CRLs shall be generated using SHA-256 or SHA-384, as appropriate for the key length.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RSA signatures on certificates that are issued after December 31, 2010 and before January 1, 2014, to CAs that issued certificates prior to December 31, 2010 may be generated using SHA-1 provided that CA issues no additional end entity certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additionally, certificates issued to OCSP responders that include SHA-1 certificates may be signed using SHA-1 until December 31, 2013.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that issue certificates signed with SHA-224 or SHA-256 after December 31, 2010 must not issue certificates signed with SHA-1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where implemented, CSSs shall sign responses using the same signature algorithm, key size, and hash algorithm used by the CA to sign CRLs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: After December 31, 2010, OCSP responders that generate signatures on OCSP responses using SHA-1 shall only provide signed responses that are pre-produced (i.e., any signed response that is provided to an OCSP client shall have been signed before the OCSP responder received the request from the client).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: End entity certificates issued under id-fpki-common-devices that expire before December 31, 2010 shall contain RSA public keys that are 1024, 2048, or 3072 bits in length or elliptic curve keys that are 256 or 384 bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: End entity certificates issued under id-fpki-common-devices and id-fpki-common-devicesHardware that expire on or after December 31, 2010 shall contain RSA public keys that are 2048 or 3072 bits or elliptic curve keys that are 256 or 384 bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: End entity certificates issued under id-fpki-common-devices and id-fpki-common-devicesHardware that expire after December 31, 2030 shall contain RSA public keys that are 3072 bits or elliptic curve keys that are 256 or 384 bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: End entity certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, or id-fpki-common-cardAuth shall contain RSA public keys that are 2048 bits in length or elliptic curve keys that are 256 bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: End entity certificates issued under id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, and id-fpki-common-High shall contain RSA public keys that are 2048 or 3072 bits or elliptic curve keys that are 256 or 384 bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Use of TLS or another protocol providing similar security to accomplish any of the requirements of this CP shall require (1) triple-DES or AES for the symmetric key through December 31, 2010 and AES for the symmetric key after December 31, 2010 and (2) at least 1024 bit RSA or 163 bit elliptic curve keys through December 31, 2008, at least 2048 bit RSA or 224 bit elliptic curve keys after December 31, 2008, and 3072 bit RSA or at least 256 bit elliptic curve keys after December 31, 2030.

groups.title: 7.1.5 Public Key Parameters Generation and Quality Checking
Public Key Parameters Generation and Quality Checking Controls

controls.title: Public Key Parameters Generation and Quality Checking

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Elliptic Curve public key parameters shall always be selected from the set specified in section 7.1.3.

groups.title: 7.1.6 Key Usage Purposes (as per X.509 v3 Key Usage Field)
Key Usage Purposes (as per X.509 v3 Key Usage Field) Controls

controls.title: Key Usage Purposes (as per X.509 v3 Key Usage Field)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of a specific key is constrained by the key usage extension in the X.509 certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All certificates shall include a critical key usage extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public keys that are bound into subscriber user certificates shall be used only for signing or encrypting, but not both.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: User certificates that assert id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, id-fpki-common-cardAuth, or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth shall only assert the *digitalSignature* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Other user certificates to be used for digital signatures shall assert both the *digitalSignature* and *nonRepudiation* bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: User certificates that contain RSA public keys that are to be used for key transport shall assert the *keyEncipherment* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: User certificates that contain elliptic curve public keys that are to be used for key agreement shall assert the *keyAgreement* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public keys that are bound into CA certificates shall be used only for signing certificates and status information (e.g., CRLs).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates whose subject public key is to be used to verify other certificates shall assert the *keyCertSign* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates whose subject public key is to be used to verify CRLs shall assert the *cRLSign* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates whose subject public key is to be used to verify Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responses shall assert the *digitalSignature* and/or *nonRepudiation* bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public keys that are bound into device certificates may be used for digital signature (including authentication), key management, or both.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device certificates to be used for digital signatures shall assert the *digitalSignature* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device certificates that contain RSA public keys that are to be used for key transport shall assert the *keyEncipherment* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device certificates that contain elliptic curve public keys that are to be used for key agreement shall assert the *keyAgreement* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device certificates to be used for both digital signatures and key management shall assert the *digitalSignature* bit and either the *keyEncipherment* (for RSA) or *keyAgreement* (for elliptic curve) bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device certificates shall not assert the *nonRepudiation* bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The *dataEncipherment*, *encipherOnly*, and *decipherOnly* bits shall not be asserted in certificates issued under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For End Entity certificates issued after June 30, 2019, the Extended Key Usage extension shall always be present and shall not contain *anyExtendedKeyUsage* {2.5.29.37.0}.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Extended Key Usage OIDs shall be consistent with key usage bits asserted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a certificate is used for authentication of ephemeral keys, the Key Usage bit in the certificate must assert the *digitalSignature* bit and may or may not assert *keyEncryption* and *keyAgreement* depending on the public key in the SPKI of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Signing certificates issued under the policy for id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning shall include an extended key usage of *id-PIV-content-signing* (see \[CCP-PROF\]).

groups.title: 7.1 Private Key Protection and Cryptographic Module Engineering Controls
Cryptographic Module Standards and Controls Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The relevant standard for cryptographic modules is *Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules* \[FIPS 140-2\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic modules shall be validated to a FIPS 140 level identified in this section.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In accordance with FIPS 201, the relevant NIST Guideline for PIV Card Issuers (PCI) and Derived PIV Credential Issuers is NIST SP 800-79, *Guidelines for the Accreditation of PCIs and Derived PIV Credential* *Issuers* (DPCI), which utilizes various aspects of NIST SP 800-37 and applies them to accrediting the reliability of PCIs and DPCIs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that issue certificates under id-fpki-common-High shall use a FIPS 140 Level 3 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that do not issue certificates under id-fpki-common-High shall use a FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RAs shall use a FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV Cards are PKI tokens that have private keys associated with certificates asserting id-fpki-common-authentication or id-fpki-common-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV Cards shall only be issued using card stock that has been tested and approved by the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program and listed on the GSA [Approved Products List](http://www.idmanagement.gov/approved-products-list-apl) (APL).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV-I cards have private keys associated with certificates asserting id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV-I cards issued by federal executive branch agencies and the certification authorities operating under this policy shall only be issued using card stock that has been tested and approved by the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program and listed on the GSA [Approved Products List](http://www.idmanagement.gov/approved-products-list-apl) (APL).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Card stock that has been removed from the APL may continue to be issued for no more than one year after GSA approved replacement card stock is available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Smart cards issued using the deprecated card stock may continue to be used until the current subscriber certificates expire, unless otherwise notified by the FPKIPA/FPKIMA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On an annual basis, for each PCI configuration used (as defined by the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program), one populated, representative sample PIV and/or PIV-I Card shall be submitted to the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program for testing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers shall use a FIPS 140 Level 1 or higher validated cryptographic module for all cryptographic operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers issued certificates under the hardware users policy (id-fpki-common-hardware or id-fpki-common-devicesHardware), one of the authentication policies (id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-cardAuth, or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth), or common High policy (id-fpki-common-High) shall use a FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module for all private key operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSSes that provide status information for certificates issued under id-fpki-common-High shall use a FIPS 140 Level 3 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSSes that do not provide status information for certificates issued under id-fpki-common-High shall use a FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module.

groups.title: 7.2.1 Private Key (n out of m) Multi-Person Control
Private Key (n out of m) Multi-Person Control Controls

controls.title: Private Key (n out of m) Multi-Person Control

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A single person shall not be permitted to activate or access any cryptographic module that contains the complete CA private signing key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA signature keys may be backed up only under two-person control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to CA signing keys backed up for disaster recovery shall be under at least two-person control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The names of the parties used for two-person control shall be maintained on a list that shall be made available for inspection during compliance audits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private keys are never escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Human subscriber key management keys shall be escrowed to provide key recovery as described in section 4.12.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a device has a separate key management key certificate, the key management private key may be escrowed.

groups.title: 7.2.4.0 Backup of CA Private Signature Key
Backup of CA Private Signature Key Controls

controls.title: Backup of CA Private Signature Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA private signature keys shall be backed up under the same multiperson control as the original signature key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one copy of the private signature key shall be stored off-site.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All copies of the CA private signature key shall be accounted for and protected in the same manner as the original.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backup procedures shall be included in the CA’s CPS.

groups.title: 7.2.4.1 Backup of Subscriber Private Signature Key
Backup of Subscriber Private Signature Key Controls

controls.title: Backup of Subscriber Private Signature Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber private signature keys whose corresponding public key is contained in a certificate asserting the id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-cardAuth, id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth, or id-fpki-common-High policy shall not be backed up or copied.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All other Subscriber private signature keys may be backed up or copied, but must be held in the subscriber’s control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backed up subscriber private signature keys shall not be stored in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Storage must ensure security controls consistent with the protection provided by the subscriber’s cryptographic module.

groups.title: 7.2.4.2 Backup of Subscriber Private Key Management Key
Backup of Subscriber Private Key Management Key Controls

controls.title: Backup of Subscriber Private Key Management Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backed up subscriber private key management keys shall not be stored in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Storage must ensure security controls consistent with the protection provided by the subscriber’s cryptographic module.

groups.title: Backup of CSS Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSS private keys may be backed up.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If backed up, all copies shall be accounted for and protected in the same manner as the original.

groups.title: Backup of Device Private Keys Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device private keys may be backed up or copied, but must be held under the control of the device’s human sponsor or other authorized administrator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backed up device private keys shall not be stored in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Storage must ensure security controls consistent with the protection provided by the device’s cryptographic module.

groups.title: 7.2.4.5 Backup of Common PIV Content Signing Key
Backup of Common PIV Content Signing Key Controls

controls.title: Backup of Common PIV Content Signing Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Common PIV Content Signing private signature keys shall be backed up under multi-person control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one copy of the private signature key shall be stored in a secondary location.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All copies of the Common PIV Content Signing private signature key shall be accounted for and protected in the same manner as the original.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backed up Common PIV

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content private signature keys shall not be exported or stored in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backup procedures shall be documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private signature keys and subscriber private signatures keys shall not be archived.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that retain subscriber private encryption keys for business continuity purposes shall archive such subscriber private keys, in accordance with section 5.5.

groups.title: 7.2.5 Private Key Transfer into or from a Cryptographic Module
Private Key Transfer into or from a Cryptographic Module Controls

controls.title: Private Key Transfer into or from a Cryptographic Module

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private keys may be exported from the cryptographic module only to perform CA key backup procedures as described in section 6.2.4.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At no time shall the CA private key exist in plaintext outside the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All other keys shall be generated by and in a cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event that a private key is to be transported from one cryptographic module to another, the private key must be encrypted during transport; private keys must never exist in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Private or symmetric keys used to encrypt other private keys for transport must be protected from disclosure.

groups.title: 7.2.6 Private Key Storage on Cryptographic Module
Private Key Storage on Cryptographic Module Controls

controls.title: Private Key Storage on Cryptographic Module

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation beyond that specified in FIPS 140.

groups.title: Method of Activating Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, and id-fpki-common-High, the subscriber must be authenticated to the cryptographic token before the activation of the associated private key(s).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Acceptable means of authentication include but are not limited to passphrases, PINs or biometrics.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When passphrases or PINs are used, they shall be a minimum of six (6) characters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Entry of activation data shall be protected from disclosure (i.e., the data should not be displayed while it is entered).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-devices and id-fpki-common-devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hardware, the device may be configured to activate its private key without requiring its human sponsor or authorized administrator to authenticate to the cryptographic token, provided that appropriate physical and logical access controls are implemented for the device and its cryptographic token.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning, the PIV card issuance system or device may be configured to activate its private key without requiring its human sponsor or authorized administrator to authenticate to the cryptographic token, provided that appropriate physical and logical access controls are implemented for content signing operations conformant with PIV issuance requirements (see \[FIPS 201\]).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The strength of the security controls shall be commensurate with the level of threat in the device’s environment, and shall protect the device’s hardware, software, and the cryptographic token and its activation data from compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-cardAuth or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth, subscriber authentication is not required to use the associated private key.

groups.title: Method of Deactivating Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic modules that have been activated shall not be available to unauthorized access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: After use, the cryptographic module shall be deactivated, e.g., via a manual logout procedure or automatically after a period of inactivity as defined in the applicable CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA cryptographic modules shall be removed and stored in a secure container when not in use.

groups.title: Method of Destroying Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals in trusted roles shall destroy CA, RA, and CSS (e.g., OCSP server) private signature keys when they are no longer needed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers shall either surrender their cryptographic module to CA/RA personnel for destruction or destroy their private signature keys, when they are no longer needed or when the certificates to which they correspond expire or are revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical destruction of hardware is not required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To ensure future access to encrypted data, subscriber private key management keys should be secured in long-term backups or archived.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Practice Note: Destruction will likely be performed by executing a “zeroize” command.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See section 6.2.1.

groups.title: 7.2 Other Aspects of Key Pair Management

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The public key is archived as part of the certificate archival.

groups.title: 7.3.1 Certificate Operational Periods and Key Usage Periods
Certificate Operational Periods and Key Usage Periods Controls

controls.title: Certificate Operational Periods and Key Usage Periods

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The usage period for the Common Policy Root CA key pair is a maximum of 20 years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, the usage period for a CA key pair is a maximum of ten years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA private key may be used to sign certificates for at most four years, but may be used to sign CRLs and OCSP responder certificates for the entire usage period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All certificates signed by a specific CA key pair must expire before the end of that key pair’s usage period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber public keys in certificates that assert the id-PIV-content-signing or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning OID in the extended key usage extension have a maximum usage period of nine years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The private keys corresponding to the public keys in these certificates have a maximum usage period of three years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Expiration of the id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning certificate shall be later than the expiration of the credential’s id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, or id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For OCSP responders operating under this policy and all other subscriber public keys, the maximum usage period is three years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber signature private keys have the same usage period as their corresponding public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The usage period for subscriber key management private keys is not restricted.

groups.title: Activation Data Generation and Installation Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA activation data may be user-selected (by each of the multiple parties holding that activation data).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the activation data must be transmitted, it shall be via an appropriately protected channel, and distinct in time and place from the associated cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA and subscriber activation data may be user-selected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The strength of the activation data shall meet or exceed the requirements for authentication mechanisms stipulated for Level 2 in FIPS 140‑2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the activation data must be transmitted, it shall be via an appropriately protected channel, and distinct in time and place from the associated cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data used to unlock private keys shall be protected from disclosure by a combination of cryptographic and physical access control mechanisms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Activation data shall be:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - memorized;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - biometric in nature; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The system development controls for the CA and RA are as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA shall use software that has been designed and developed under a formal, documented development methodology.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Hardware and software procured to operate the CA shall be purchased in a fashion to reduce the likelihood that any particular component was tampered with (e.g., by ensuring the vendor cannot identify the PKI component that will be installed on a particular device).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Hardware and software developed specifically for the CA shall be developed in a controlled environment, and the development process shall be defined and documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This requirement does not apply to commercial off-the-shelf hardware or software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA hardware and software, including the VME hypervisor, shall be dedicated to operating and supporting the CA (i.e., the systems and services dedicated to the issuance and management of certificates).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There shall be no other applications, hardware devices, network connections, or component software installed that are not parts of the CA operation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the CA operation supports multiple CAs, the hardware platform may support multiple CAs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In a VME, a single hypervisor may support multiple CAs and their supporting systems, provided all systems have comparable security controls and are dedicated to the support of the CA.

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Proper care shall be taken to prevent malicious software from being loaded onto the CA equipment.

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Hardware and software updates shall be purchased or developed in the same manner as original equipment, and shall be installed by trusted and trained personnel in a defined manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The configuration of the CA system, in addition to any modifications and upgrades, shall be documented and controlled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There shall be a mechanism for detecting unauthorized modification to the software or configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA software, when first loaded, shall be verified as being that supplied from the vendor, with no modifications, and be the version intended for use.

parts.name: statement

groups.title: Compliance Audit and Other Assessments Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy are subject to an annual review by the FPKIPA to ensure their policies and operations remain compliant with this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy shall have a compliance audit mechanism in place to ensure that the requirements of their CPS are being implemented and enforced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The SSP PMA shall be responsible for ensuring audits are conducted for all PKI functions regardless of how or by whom the PKI components are managed and operated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Common Policy Root CA, the FPKIMA shall have a compliance audit mechanism in place to ensure that the requirements of this CP are being implemented and enforced by its CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This specification does not impose a requirement for any particular assessment methodology.

groups.title: Frequency or Circumstances of Assessment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs and RAs operating under this policy shall be subject to a periodic compliance audit at least once per year in accordance with the *FPKI Annual Review Requirements* document \[AUDIT\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Further, the FPKIPA has the right to require aperiodic compliance audits of CAs operating under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall state the reason for any aperiodic compliance audit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The auditor must demonstrate competence in the field of compliance audits, and must be thoroughly familiar with the CA’s CPS and this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The compliance auditor must perform such compliance audits as a regular ongoing business activity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to the previous requirements, the auditor must be a certified information system auditor (CISA) or IT security specialist, and a PKI subject matter specialist who can offer input regarding acceptable risks, mitigation strategies, and industry best practices.

groups.title: Assessor’s Relationship to Assessed Entity Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The compliance auditor either shall be a private firm that is independent from the entities (CA and RAs) being audited, or it shall be sufficiently organizationally separated from those entities to provide an unbiased, independent evaluation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An example of the latter situation may be an Agency inspector general.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To insure independence and objectivity, the compliance auditor may not have served the entity in developing or maintaining the entity’s CA Facility or certificate practices statement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA shall determine whether a compliance auditor meets this requirement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Agency PMA is responsible for identifying and engaging a qualified auditor of agency operations implementing aspects of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The purpose of a compliance audit shall be to verify that a CA operated by a SSP and all RAs of that CA comply with all the requirements of the current versions of the Federal Common Policy Root CA CP and the SSP’s CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All aspects of the CA/RA operation shall be subject to compliance audit inspections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Components other than CAs may be audited fully or by using a representative sample.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the auditor uses statistical sampling, all PKI components, PKI component managers and operators shall be considered in the sample.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The samples shall vary on an annual basis.

groups.title: 9.4 Actions Taken as a Result of Deficiency
Actions Taken as a Result of Deficiency Controls

controls.title: Actions Taken as a Result of Deficiency

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When the compliance auditor finds a discrepancy between the requirements of this CP or the stipulations in the CPS and the design, operation, or maintenance of the PKI Authorities, the following actions shall be performed:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The compliance auditor shall note the discrepancy;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The compliance auditor shall notify the responsible party promptly; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The party responsible for correcting the discrepancy will propose a remedy, including expected time for completion, to the FPKIPA and appropriate Agency PMA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Depending upon the nature and severity of the discrepancy, and how quickly it can be corrected, the FPKIPA may decide to temporarily halt operation of the CA or RA, to revoke a certificate issued to the CA or RA, or take other actions it deems appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will develop procedures for making and implementing such determinations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In accordance with section 8.1, a compliance audit may be required to confirm the implementation and effectiveness of the remedy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On an annual basis, an Auditor Letter of Compliance, prepared in accordance with the *FPKI Annual Review Requirements* document, on behalf of an Agency PMA shall be provided to the SSP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On an annual basis, the SSP PMA shall submit an annual review package to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This package shall be prepared by the SSP PMA, in accordance with the *FPKI Annual Review Requirements* document and include an assertion that all PKI components have been audited - including any components that may be separately managed and operated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The report shall identify the versions of this CP and the CPS used in the assessment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additionally, where necessary, the results shall be communicated as set forth in section 8.5 above.
